ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about Mediterranean and Western worlds from 284 to 1000, specifically the manner in which the Roman Empire declined and fell, and whether it was a catastrophe or a transformation. We also covered the rise of Christianity and whether the Dark Ages are actually as "dark" as they seem.
I gained an overall understanding of the history of early middle ages.
Learned more about how Europe went from the age of antiquity to medieval and beyond.
I learned a lot about the early Middle Ages!

I learned about the fall of the Roman Empire, succeeding powerful kingdoms such as the Byzantine Empire, Umayyad and Abassid Caliphates, Merovingians, Carolingians, Germanic tribes, Vikings, among other groups. We covered religious, political, economic, and cultural changes primarily between the 4th and 10th centuries, and were able to delve into more specific historians and intellectuals (primary and secondary sources) relating to this period.
The course does what it says. Learned a good deal about the early Middle Ages, especially Merovingian and Carolingian Francia.
I learned a lot about the early Middle Ages and some important ideas about religion. Very fascinating
History from the Fall of the Western half of the Roman empire to the rise of the Vikings. Much work with primary sources and secondary scholarship
A good understanding of the changes and continuities from the late Roman Empire to the medieval scene in 1000

I gained a broad understanding of the early Middle Ages. This means the rise of Christianity, the fall of Rome, the Arab conquests, the trials and tribulations of the Byzantines, and the formation of modern Europe with Charlemagne's empire.
This course gave me added knowledge about the period's key players, important developments, and mixture of continuity and catastrophe. I felt that I learned a good deal from the course.
How to write a proper research paper and well-develop a research question

history of Europe from the reign of Diocletian to the year 1000; the course challenges the typical view of this time period as the "Dark Ages," and that even after the fall of the Western Roman Empire a lot of important and interesting stuff happened in Europe (i.e. the creation of Islam, the Byzantine Empire, the rise of the Roman Catholic Church, the suppression of Christian heresies, the Viking conquests, the Franks and later Charlemagne, the advancement of math and science, etc.)

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Freedman's lectures were very insightful and engaging, and discussion sections were extremely helpful in reviewing and understanding the material. The assigned readings were extremely long, such that it was impossible to read everything thoroughly, and instead I had to skim for the key points; however, this is not necessarily a weakness because I still felt that skimming the reading was enhancing my understanding of the material and allowing me to obtain a wide breadth of knowledge about each topic.
Was a great class overall. Loved the content and the prof, not complaints

The recordings were really not good quality so I often watched the recorded lectures from about 10 years ago on YouTube. I would never be sure if there were something I missed unless I watched both. Its also interesting the class hasnt changed much over the past decade. Other than that the content was interesting. Sometimes it was hard to tell what the important themes were but this was always clarified in section.

The course covers an immense amount of time and vast regions in what would become parts of Europe, Asia, and Africa, mostly in chronological order. The readings can be quite long and hard to complete in a given week. Sections provided opportunities to expand on the material. The exams were comprehensive but approachable, and provided opportunities to demonstrate specific interests within the material. The availability of recorded lectures on Yale Open Courses was really helpful.

Although the breadth of the course was helpful, a bit more specificity might have been preferable. Courses on Byzantium, the post-Roman West, early Islam, or the Anglo-Saxons, Irish, and Vikings would all be interesting and might be able to cover more details. I felt like I did not get a great sense of Visigothic Spain, for example, and going completely chronologically made it feel like there may have been more of a gap between Clovis and Charlemagne than there really was.
The course is very well structured. My only wish is sometimes the lectures could be more focused. But, it is a great course

Strengths: Interesting lectures, organized efficiently, and very well laid out expectations. Great reading list for the class
Weaknesses: Barely any slides which made it hard to follow the class, especially during the more complex periods of the class

The class unfolds in a way that gives us a taste of the breadth of history that is to be learned of this often overlooked period. 
The readings are interesting as well.
Professor Freedman is a great lecturer and was accessible throughout the semester.
This class has stood the test of time. Freedman has been teaching it for a while and he has it down. The TFs were also very competent. This is a well-organized well thought out class.

It was taught very well, and tightly, by Professor Freedman and the TF's. The material was always relevant and was always the focus of the instructors, and the mixture of secondary and primary sources was a key strength.
My TF was quite challenging and rude to students who made mistakes. I wish this class was seminar because I think I would have interacted with the readings in a more meaningful way.

Strengths: great Professor and teaching team, the course itself isn't very stressful (only one short essay, a final paper, a midterm, and a final exam); very straightforward history survey lecture, but interesting material; also, all lectures were recorded, and you can also find the transcripts of Prof Freedman's 2011 lectures from Yale online; the final paper assignment was a primary source analysis paper, and it was a very valuable experience to read obscure Middle Ages texts and write a paper on them; grading did not seem very strict || Weaknesses: sometimes it was a little hard to see the bigger picture through Prof Freedman's lectures, but once it all clicked the information was really interesting (and I found looking at the transcripts from his publicly available 2011 lectures for the same course to be extremely useful to supplement the current course lectures); also a significant portion of the first half of the course is about the expansion and suppression of various Christian heresies, and while some might find this interesting, if you don't have an existing framework of understanding about Christianity you might get a little lost without some outside reading/studying

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course, even if you're not interested in the Middle Ages; this course increased my fascination with the time period, in which I had had little interest before.
Yes! It's an interesting history course about a topic that is not often discussed.
Yes - great course with great content and great prof
Anyone who likes history should take this.

I would recommend this course to another student. For anyone interested in religious history, or the development of modern states, this course demonstrated not only the continuities of a very far away period, but also how technology and resources have shifted over time. It was really engaging and interesting, and I believe most history majors would benefit from learning the material.

Yes, this is a great course for anyone interested in learning more about the late antique period or the history of Europe after the fall of the Western Roman Empire. Anyone who wants to learn more about what happens between the fall of the Roman Empire and the high middle ages would benefit from this class.
Yes. The early Middle Ages is a very interesting yet oft-forgotten period of history and was a formational one for the West.
Yes, Dr. Freedman is awesome, and I'd recommend taking his other course (The History of Food) as well. Great professor with some great classes.

This class is designed so that if you engage with the material and lectures, you can do well. However, I recommend briefly reviewing the developments during this period, as some find the content itself interesting and others do not. There were less interesting moments or confusing parts of the course, which made it hard to engage at times. However, the papers did foster deeper understanding of the class content.
Yes, the early Middle Ages is a rich and fascinating period.
Yes. If you are interested in modern Western history or religious history you have to know how the modern world came to be, this class helped me gain that understanding.
Yes. This was a good course taught by good people in a good way.
Yes I would. It definitely has a higher work demand than other history lecture but I think that level of engagement with the material might be necessary for true understanding.
Yes, if the subject matter interests you and if you are in need of a preindustrial credit.
